symptoms.name: Shock
symptoms.pattern: Common in gastrointestinal, inhalational, and injectional anthrax; less common in cutaneous anthrax

symptoms.name: Painless or pruritic papule
symptoms.pattern: Initial skin lesion in cutaneous anthrax, progressing to vesicle, ulcer, and black eschar

symptoms.name: Edema
symptoms.pattern: Disproportionate edema associated with cutaneous anthrax lesions; can cause airway compromise in face or neck infections

symptoms.name: Respiratory symptoms
symptoms.pattern: Can be a clue to anthrax infection, especially in clusters of patients

symptoms.name: Pulmonary edema
symptoms.pattern: Observed in inhalational anthrax and in some cases of sepsis

symptoms.name: Hemorrhagic lesions
symptoms.pattern: Observed in the lungs in some cases of sepsis

symptoms.name: Serosanguinous pleural effusions
symptoms.pattern: Observed in the lungs in some cases of sepsis

symptoms.name: Intra-alveolar edema
symptoms.pattern: Observed in the lungs in some cases of sepsis

symptoms.name: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
symptoms.pattern: Observed in some cases of sepsis

symptoms.name: Systemic inflammation
symptoms.pattern: Observed in some cases of sepsis

symptoms.name: Changes in vascular permeability
symptoms.pattern: Observed in some cases of sepsis

symptoms.name: Persistent somatic symptoms
symptoms.pattern: Reported in survivors one year post-infection, affecting multiple body systems

symptoms.name: Psychological distress
symptoms.pattern: Reported in survivors one year post-infection

vital_signs.respiratory_rate: Tachypnea (common in shock and pulmonary involvement)

physical_findings: Painless or pruritic papule progressing to vesicle, ulcer, and black eschar (cutaneous anthrax)

imaging_findings.chest_x-ray: Pulmonary edema, infiltrates (inhalational anthrax and sepsis)

required: Positive blood cultures for Bacillus anthracis
Gram stain and culture from blood or surgical specimens showing gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria
supportive: History of exposure to risk factors
